repnme.cdata!:
China - Yangtze Flood Emergency
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, though
            institutional development impacts were only modest. Valuable
            lessons were learned from project implementation, and
            supervision, particularly that processing the project under
            an emergency recovery lending following a "fast
            track" within three to four years, proved realistic, a
            practice which could be replicated in China, and elsewhere.
            Nonetheless, the size of each subproject should be given
            careful attention, since some subprojects were comparatively
            large, and implementation turned less than satisfactory due
            to work complexity, and time-frame longer than expected.
            Conversely, the flexible approach adopted in the procurement
            process, where small subprojects underwent the national
            shopping process, and larger subprojects the national
            competitive bidding, facilitated an effective procurement
            process. However, counterpart funding constraints led to
            some subprojects being dropped; the reason being that under
            the principle of the "beneficiary pays",
            provincial governments were reluctant to assist those
            counties unable to raise required funds, and thus service
            the Bank loan/credit. To this end, the blend in project
            lending (partly loan, and partly credit) could preferably
            benefit from the use of credit lending for non-revenue
            generating subprojects (flood protection, and social
            sectors), using the loan portion for infrastructure works,
            thus collecting fees for loan servicing. Finally, the active
            participation, and effective coordination of local
            governments, inter-agencies, and end-users, greatly
            facilitated project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Yangtze Flood Emergency
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Yangtze Flood Emergency
            Rehabilitation Project aims to rebuild social and economic
            infrastructure damaged by the devastating floods in Hubei,
            Hunan, and Jiangxi provinces, thereby rapidly restoring
            economic production and social services. In the project
            design, priority has been given to restoring and rebuilding
            the water supply and health facilities to prevent the spread
            of diseases after the floods, and roads to restore key
            access to the flooded areas so as to regenerate economic
            activities. The main components are restoration and
            reconstruction of roads, water supply systems, county and
            township secondary and primary schools, hospitals, health
            centers and clinics, and irrigation systems. The project
            also provides for each province to upgrade existing or
            developing flood forecasting, and simulation and dispatch
            systems, taking into account the recent flood experience.

China - Yangtze Flood Emergency
